Award.AwardTitle: Constructing and Validating an Automated Coding System for Electronic News Sources

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project builds, tests, and validates an open-source automated system for coding social movement data from electronically available news sources. Although no source is perfect, scholars agree that the best general source of such data, specifically that on social protest, is a compilation of a large number of news sources. This project draws on the advances in machine learning developed in computer science and statistics and combining them with our deep substantive knowledge as sociologists of the problems of identifying and coding collective action events in news sources. An existing highly-regarded hand-coded data set based on the New York Times is used as the reference for "training" machine learning algorithms -- called "classifiers" -- to recognize elements of an action event in a news article and extract relevant information. We also collect and hand-code new data drawn from other regional, national, and international news sources to provide additional training sets to increase the range and variety of protests we are able to detect. A supplement to the project provides research experience for undergraduates who will be involved in collecting and coding these new data.

This project builds, tests, and validates an open-source automated system for coding data from electronically available news sources. It advances the state of data collection in social science and employs the latest developments in natural language processing and supervised machine learning within computer science and statistics. The result will be an open-source, publicly available system that may be used by other researchers and further improved and expanded.

This project promises to provide an important new methodological tool of broad interdisciplinary value to social scientists and to open the door to more efficiently compiling collective action-data from news sources that can improve both academic scholarship and public policy. All of the code for this project will be released under an open-source license and publicly accessible through a public source code repository. This work will be accessible and useful to scholars in social movements, international relations, and foreign policy. The work will also be of use to a large number of non-academics, such as foreign policy analysts and decision-makers, journalists, and those interested in computational methods of textual analysis and classification. The ability to code collective action data more efficiently and accurately from news sources has broad policy applicability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Social scientists have long studied the dynamics and outcomes of social movements. Scholarly and public interests in social movements have further grown in recent years as social movements from a wide ideological spectrum have arisen to influence public opinions and policies, both in the United States and abroad. However, research on social movements has been hampered by the difficulty of collecting large scale data about social movement activities. Newspapers have been the major source of information for social movement research, but the high cost of hand-coding protest events from news sources has limited the scope of data collection.


This project developed a new open-source automated system, the Machine-learning Protest Event Data System (MPEDS), that makes more efficient and less expensive the large-scale coding of social movement activities from electronic news sources. The new system incorporates the tools from machine learning and computational linguistics into the conventional hand-coding approach to generate rich protest event data of high quality that are actually useful for social movement research. We trained and tested the system using a highly regarded social movement event data archive as well as new datasets we hand-coded from various sources.


The results from training/testing and the first test-run of MPEDS offer a number of insights on coding of social movement activities from news sources.

First, MPEDS is effective in identifying news articles that contain information about protest events, the task we call “haystack” task. This is the first and time-consuming step in coding protest events. Our results suggest that this phase can be successfully automated.

Second, our automated coding system works better for some sources than for others. MPEDS is more accurate in identifying protest events in news wire services, but less accurate in local newspapers. More importantly, we find that training the system on multiple news sources significantly improves its performance in all sources.

Third, MPEDS also works effectively in coding “close-ended” information, such as protest forms, issues, and targets. It does make errors in classifying this information, but we find that its errors mirror those by human-coders, indicating that such errors reflect the inherent ambiguity and difficulty of coding this information in some cases. The results show that our automated methods can be as effective as human coders in these tasks, but with advantages in replicability, reproducibility, and speed.

Fourth, although we have made a significant progress, the open-ended task of extracting the information on social movement organizations and protest location remains a challenge. We will continue to work on this task and update any progress in the public version of the system.


Most importantly, our results, especially from the first test-run of MPEDS to study Black protests, demonstrate that while some of the key tasks in generating protest event data can be effectively automated, it still requires human intervention to generate high quality data for social movement research. In particular, MPEDS performs poorly in identifying multiple events reported in a single article. It also fails to identify the links among multiple reports of a same event in different articles. These are critical shortcomings because a protest event is often mentioned in the context of related events or a larger campaign in the same article. The same event also frequently appears in multiple articles, both on different dates in the same source and across multiple sources. Any protest event data that ignores these links can yield misleading trends and patterns. Our detailed investigation of a subset of data from the human-coded Dynamics of Collective Action data set revealed that human coders also were inconsistent in identifying multiple events in the same article and recognizing “duplicates,” i.e. references to the same event in different articles. In short, this is a difficult task for either humans or machines.


Although we and others will continue to work on automating the identification of distinct events within news stories and the identification of duplicates, we  believe that the hybrid approach combining human intervention with machine coding is optimal for now. Based on our test-run of MPEDS, we developed a hybrid approach combining the automated coding with hand-coding. Our approach includes a detailed protocol for retaining and documenting the information about multiple reports on the same event and multiple events reported in the same article. MPEDS and the coding web interface we developed make these complex tasks doable and efficient for human coders. The results are rich and reproducible data with systematic documentation that can be useful for social scientific research of social movement activities.  


In summary, this project contributes to our understanding of the dynamics of protest and other forms of collective action by 1) creating a new automated coding system, 2) developing a new web interface for hand-coding, 3) proposing a new protocol that combines machine and human-coding for the optimal result, and 4) providing new rich training and testing datasets.
